metadata.title: YouTube Studio Setup on Budget 2025: Affordable Equipment Guide
metadata.description: Build YouTube studio affordably. Budget equipment recommendations for quality content.

hero.headline: YouTube Studio Setup on Budget
hero.subheadline: Professional-looking content without breaking the bank. Smart choices matter.

sections.content: You don't need expensive gear to make great YouTube contentâ€”proof is everywhere on the platform. The key is knowing where to invest and where to save. Audio matters more than video quality. Lighting matters more than camera. Here's how to build a capable setup affordably.

content.title: 1. Audio First
content.description: Bad audio kills videos. $50-100 budget mic transforms quality.

content.title: 2. Lighting Second
content.description: Good lighting makes any camera look better. $30-50 ring light works.

content.title: 3. Camera Third
content.description: Your phone is probably fine to start. Upgrade later if needed.

content.title: Audio: Fifine K669B (~$30)
content.description: USB condenser mic. Surprisingly good. Great starter.

content.title: Lighting: Ring Light (~$30)
content.description: Basic ring light with stand. Even lighting on face.

content.title: Camera: Your Phone
content.description: Modern phones have great cameras. Use what you have.

sections.title: Budget Build Path
content: Upgrade individual items as budget allows

sections.title: Money-Saving Tips
content: Phone cameras are genuinely good now
Natural light is free and beautiful

faq.question: Absolute minimum to start?
faq.answer: Phone + free editing software + natural light. Add $30 mic when possible. That's genuinely enough to create good content.

faq.question: Should I buy camera or phone gimbal?
faq.answer: Neither initially. Tripod or phone mount more useful. Stabilization can be added in software. Invest in audio first.

faq.question: When to upgrade from phone?
faq.answer: When you've made 50+ videos and know exactly what you need. Most creators upgrade too early. Master what you have first.

faq.question: Best budget upgrade?
faq.answer: Almost always audio. $100 on better mic/interface beats $500 on camera. Viewers tolerate mediocre video; bad audio makes them leave.
